translated: Jātaka🔽The Minor Collection
The Chapter with Pairs
The Suruci Jātaka🔽“First I was brought here
as the wife of the great king Suruci.
For ten thousand years
he brought me to Suruci.

analyzed: sā aham brāhmaṇa  veda iham  na abhijānāmi kāyena
translated: I do not recall, brahmin,🔽with body, speech, or mind,

analyzed: vācāya uda cetasā  su rucim atimaññittha
translated: ever slighting Suruci,
whether in public or in private.
By this declaration of the truth,
may a son be born to you, my lord.
If I have spoken falsely,
may my head split into seven pieces.

original: Bhattu mama sassu mātā,🔽pitā cāpi ca sassuro;
analyzed: bhattu mama sassu mātā  pitā ca api ca sa ssuraḥ
translated: My father-in-law, my mother-in-law,🔽and my husband, the king of Videha,
were my teachers, brahmin,
for as long as they lived.
I was devoted to non-violence,
to desire, and to the practice of the Teaching.
I served them respectfully,
diligent throughout the day and night.
By this declaration of the truth,
may a son be born to you, my lord.
If I have spoken falsely,
may my head split into seven pieces.
Brahmin, I had sixteen thousand wives,
and I never felt envy or anger
I have never done so.
I rejoice in their welfare,
and I have no one I dislike;
I have compassion for myself,
always towards all my enemies.
By this declaration of the truth,
may a son be born to you, my lord;
If I have spoken falsely,
may my head split into seven pieces.
To slaves, servants, and workmen,
and to others who depend on me,
I send them off with the Dhamma,
always with senses delighted.
By this declaration of the truth,
may a son be born to you, my lord;
If I have spoken falsely,
may my head split into seven pieces.
To ascetics and brahmins,
and to other wanderers,
I give them food and drink,
always with my hand raised in generosity.
By this declaration of the truth,
may a son be born to you, my lord;
If I have spoken falsely,
may my head split into seven pieces.
On the fourteenth, fifteenth,
and the eighth of the fortnight,
And on the observance days,🔽Endowed with the eight factors,
I observe the Uposatha,
Always restrained in the precepts.
By this declaration of the truth,
A son will be born to you, O seer;
If I speak falsely,
May my head split into seven pieces!”
“All those qualities of Dhamma,
O famous daughter of the king;
Are present in you, O Bhaddā,
Those you praise in yourself.
A noble one, endowed with birth,
well-born, of great fame;
A Dhamma king of the Videhans,
a son will be born to you.”
“A bad one, wearing a dusty cloak,
standing in the sky without a support;
You speak gentle words,
which go to my heart.
A god from the heavenly world,
or a seer with great power;

analyzed: kaḥ vā asi tvam an uppattaḥ
translated: Who are you that have come,
tell me who you are.”
“Those who the assembly of gods,
having come together in Sudhamma;
I am Sakka, the thousand-eyed,
I have come into your presence.
Amongst women in the world of the living,
whoever is one of equal conduct;🔽Wise, virtuous,
devoted to her mother-in-law and husband.
To such a wise one,
a pure-acting woman;
The gods come to see,
the non-human ones (come) to the human one.
“And you, fair lady, by your good conduct,
and by your good conduct in a former life,
have been born in this royal family,
and have obtained all your desires.
And this son of the king,
has been successful in both worlds;
he will be reborn in the world of the gods,
and will be famous in this life.
Live long, O wise one, in happiness,
and protect your son according to the Law;
I now depart to the world of the gods,
for I love to see you.”
The Jātaka of Suruci is the sixth.
